description: The etymology of the noun is unknown, but compare Old French gigue (“a fiddle”). The verb is derived from the noun.

entries.meaning: Originally (music), a performing engagement by a musician or musical group; (by extension, film, television, theater) a job or role for a performer.
examples: I caught one of the Rolling Stones’ first gigs in Richmond.
Hey, when are we gonna get that hotel gig again?

entries.meaning: (by extension) Any job, especially one that is freelance or temporary, or done on an on-demand basis.
examples: I had this gig as a file clerk but it wasn’t my style so I left.
That guy’s got a great gig over at the bike shop. He hardly works all day.

entries.meaning: (US, military) A demerit received for some infraction of a military deportment or dress code.
examples: I received gigs for having buttons of my uniform undone.

verbs.description: gig (third-person singular simple present gigs, present participle gigging, simple past and past participle gigged) (informal)

entries.meaning: (music) To play (a musical instrument) at a gig.
(US, military) To impose a demerit (on someone) for an infraction of a military deportment or dress code.
examples: His sergeant gigged him for an unmade bunk.

entries.meaning: (film, music, television, theater) To engage in a musical performance, act in a theatre production, etc.
examples: The Rolling Stones were gigging around Richmond at the time.

entries.meaning: (by extension) To work at any job, especially one that is freelance or temporary, or done on an on-demand basis.

description: Sense 1 is a clipping of gigabyte, while sense 2 is a clipping of giga- (prefix multiplying the unit to which it is attached by one billion).

entries.meaning: (informal, computing) Clipping of gigabyte (“one billion (1,000,000,000) bytes”).
examples: This picture is almost a gig; don’t you want to resize it?
My new computer has over 500 gigs of hard drive space.

entries.meaning: (slang, chiefly sciences) Any unit of measurement having the SI prefix giga-.

description: The noun is derived from Middle English gigg, gigge, gygge (“spinning object; a top”); further origin uncertain, possibly:
Senses 2–4 are thought to derive from sense 1 (“whipping-top”), but their exact relationship is unclear.
The verb is derived from the noun.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A top which is made to spin by tying a piece of string around it and then throwing it so that the string unwinds rapidly; a whipping-top.
(chiefly Britain, school slang (Eton College), archaic or dialectal) A person with an odd appearance; also, a foolish person.
(slang, archaic or Britain, dialectal) Fun; frolics.
(obsolete) A fanciful impulse; a whim; also, a joke.
(nautical)
A small, narrow, open boat carried in a larger ship, and used for transportation between the ship and the shore, another vessel, etc.
(Southern England, by extension) A similar rowing boat or sailboat, especially one used for racing; specifically, a six-oared sea rowing boat commonly found in Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly.
(road transport, historical) A two-wheeled carriage drawn by a single horse.

verbs.description: gig (third-person singular simple present gigs, present participle gigging, simple past and past participle gigged)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make a joke, often condescendingly, at the expense of (someone); to make fun of.
examples: His older cousin was just gigging him about being in love with that girl from school.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) Sometimes followed by it: to ride in a gig (“a two-wheeled carriage drawn by a single horse”).

description: From Middle English gig, gigge, gegge, possibly either:

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A frivolous, playful, or wanton young woman; a giglet or giglot.

description: The noun is derived from a clipping of fishgig, fizgig, possibly from Spanish fisga (“harpoon”).
The verb is derived from the noun.

entries.meaning: (fishing) Synonym of fishgig or fizgig (“a spear with a barb on the end of it, used for catching fish, frogs, or other small animals”).

verbs.description: gig (third-person singular simple present gigs, present participle gigging, simple past and past participle gigged) (fishing)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To spear (fish, etc.) with a gig or fizgig.
(intransitive) To catch or fish with a gig or fizgig.
